author: killari.
content: Is there some kind of social consensus among core devs that an attack would be made against bad behaving validators? Has there been some historical talk about this scenario that I could read about?

author: killari.
content: I could see that kind of modifications are highly controversial

author: killari.
content: eg, a government could order that a validator (eg, Coinbase) are not allowed to process transactions by those that are on US sanctioned list. Would core devs deploy a fork that would slash all Coinbases validators?

author: sky.cactus
content: It has been discussed, and some of us have been trying to get a bit of an unofficial commitment from the core devs about whether they would write code against and/or support a fork that wiped out censors after the fact.

author: killari.
content: It sounds like a bit slippery slope on what is defined as censoring and what is not

author: sky.cactus
content: Yes, but the alternative is worse (allowing censorship to go unchecked).

author: sky.cactus
content: <@415548822983278593> had what I thought was a relatively bright line, which was "a group of validators that intentionally reorgs the chain or refuses to sign over valid blocks".

author: killari.
content: well, if there are still enough non censoring validators, things should be fine

author: killari.
content: ah, right if they do reorging too
